title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: At last, somewhereabout the Moffat Water, he had forgathered with a single tinker whom hehad once befriended in the old days when he had yet power to help.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: He gaed up Moffat Water and ower the muckle hill they ca'Corriefragauns, and got on nane sae bad till he cam to the awfu' craigsabune Loch Skene.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: Sair frights some o' the folk frae Megget Water got, on first coming on him unawares, — and I'm telt that there's a bairn ower-by about the side of Moffat Water — it's a callant — whose mither swarfed at the Bonassus, when she was near the doun- lying, that has a fearsome likeness till liim in the face ; but noo he's weel kent, and, I may say, hked and respeckit through a' the Forest, as a peaceable and industrious member o' society.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Two men, it is said, by name HalbertDobson and David Dun, constructed for themselvesa place of refuge in a hidden ravine of a very savagecharacter, by the side of a considerable waterfall,near the head of Moffat Water.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He had, say they, refused his upon the Bran-Law, near the head of Moffat Water,own dog any food on the morning of the battle, as- where the descent is so precipitous, that no merelyfirming, with an oath, that he should have no break- earthly horse could keep its feet, or merely mortalfast but upon the flesh of the Whigs.
